docs.title: MP14 Overview
docs.text: The Plant MIDI device is a polyphonic MIDI controller which utilizes bioelectrical signals from living organisms as a source of input, converting them into control voltages that can be interpreted as notes within any desired chromatic scale.

docs.title: Features and Compatibility
docs.text:
• Musical Scales: Bio signals that are measured can be mapped to Chromatic, Major, Minor, Indian and Dorian.
  • MIDI OFF: Pause midi messages sent to external device.
  • Open Source: Designed specifically community collaboration. Adafruit Trinket M0: Utilizes the Adafruit Trinket M0 for processing and communication.
  • Connectability: Connect to any instrument that accepts midi-In.

docs.title: Download and Install:
docs.text:
• Go to the Arduino IDE download page and download the latest version for your operating system.
  • Install the Arduino IDE following the on-screen instructions.

docs.title: Open Arduino IDE:
docs.text: • Launch the Arduino IDE on your computer.

docs.title: Add Board Manager URL:
docs.text:
• Go to Arduino > Preferences on macOS or File > Preferences on Windows.
  • In the Additional Board Manager URLs field, add the following URL: https://adafruit.github.io/arduino-board-index/package_adafruit_index.json
  • Click OK.

docs.title: Open Boards Manager:
docs.text: • Go to Tools > Board > Boards Manager.

docs.title: Install Adafruit SAMD Boards:
docs.text:
• In the Boards Manager, search for Adafruit SAMD.
  • Click Install on Adafruit SAMD Boards by Adafruit.

docs.title: Connect the Trinket M0:
docs.text: • Use a USB cable to connect the Trinket M0 to your computer.

docs.title: Select the Board:
docs.text:
• Go to Tools > Board.
  • Select Adafruit Trinket M0.

docs.title: Select the Port:
docs.text:
• Go to Tools > Port.
  • Select the port that corresponds to your Trinket M0. It should look something like COMx on Windows or /dev/cu.usbmodemxxxx on macOS.

docs.title: Open or Create a Sketch:
docs.text:
• Create a new one.
  • Copy and paste the MP14.14 code to the Arduino sketch.

docs.title: Compile the Sketch:
docs.text: • Click the checkmark icon to verify (compile) your sketch.

docs.title: Upload the Sketch:
docs.text:
• Click the right arrow icon to upload the sketch to the Trinket M0.
  • If the upload is successful, the on-board LED should start blinking.

docs.title: Driver Issues (Windows):
docs.text: • If your Trinket M0 is not recognized, you might need to install the USB driver. Follow the instructions on the Adafruit website to install the necessary drivers.

docs.title: Resetting the Trinket M0:
docs.text: • If the upload fails, double-click the reset button on the Trinket M0 to enter bootloader mode (the red LED should pulse). Try uploading the sketch again.

docs.title: Tools Needed for Assembly
docs.text:
• Soldering Iron
  • Solder
  • 3D Printer
  • Multimeter

docs.title: 555 Timer
docs.text: • Solder the 555 timer onto U6

docs.title: Power and Ground (Optional)
docs.text: The GND and PWR connectors are optional for a battery pack. The recommended voltage for the circuit is 3.5V. Two CR2032 cell batteries were tested and worked well.

docs.title: Potentiometer
docs.text: • Place the potentiometer into the R1 placement on the PCB. It should fit snug. Solder the Potentiometer onto R1

docs.title: Copper Probes
docs.text:
• Cut two pieces of the 0.9mm copper coil at around 72 millimeters.
  • Sand off the insulating layer of the coils with sanding paper. Wear gloves to protect hands from sand paper.

  • Set your digital multimeter to continuity mode. To test, touch the multimeter probes to the ends of the copper wire one at a time. If the multimeter beeps or buzzes, it indicates successful end-to-end continuity. If there is no sound, it means the insulating layer on the wire needs to be sanded more thoroughly. Test multiple areas of the probe to make sure the insulating layer is evenly sanded off.

  • Solder the two copper coil strips to U7 and U8 on the pcb.

docs.title: Resistors & Capacitors
docs.text:
Solder the resistors and capacitors

  • Resistor R5 = 220 ohm
  • Resistor R6 = 220 ohm
  • Resistor R4 = 220 ohm
  • Capacitor C2 = 1uF
  • Capacitor C1 =47uf
  • Capacitor C3 = 4.7nF

docs.title: Tactile Switch
docs.text:
• Bend all the pins on the tactile switch so that they are faced outward instead of down. Using a wire cutter or a scissor, cut the pins so they fit onto the U5 area on the PCB. Below is a picture of what it should look like before(left) and after(right).
  • With the soldering iron, solder the four onto the four pin areas of U5 then, solder the tactile switch onto U5

docs.title: Adafruit Trinket M0
docs.text:
• Snap off 2 sets of 5 header pins that come with the trinket M0. Solder the headers on to the board where the trinket M0 is outlined. The longer sides of the pins should face up.
  • Solder the trinket M0 onto the headers.

docs.title: TRS
docs.text: Solder the TRS connector to U5

docs.title: Work in a Well-Ventilated Area:
docs.text: • Always solder in a well-ventilated space to avoid inhaling fumes. Use a fume extractor if possible.

docs.title: Wear Protective Gear:
docs.text:
• Safety Glasses: Protect your eyes from solder splashes.
  • Heat-Resistant Gloves: Prevent burns from the soldering iron and hot solder.

docs.title: Use a Proper Soldering Iron Stand:
docs.text: • Always place the soldering iron in a stand when not in use to prevent accidental burns and fire hazards.

docs.title: Avoid Flammable Materials:
docs.text: • Keep your work area clear of flammable materials. Ensure the soldering iron does not come into contact with paper, plastic, or other flammable objects.

docs.title: Handle Soldering Iron Carefully:
docs.text: • Never touch the tip of the soldering iron. Be mindful of where you place your hands to avoid accidental burns.

docs.title: Clean Soldering Tip Regularly:
docs.text: • Use a damp sponge or brass wire cleaner to keep the soldering tip clean, ensuring efficient and safe soldering.

docs.title: Avoid Inhaling Solder Fumes:
docs.text: • Use lead-free solder to minimize health risks. Ensure good ventilation or use a fume extractor.

docs.title: Properly Dispose of Waste:
docs.text: • Dispose of used solder and electronic components according to local regulations. Do not throw them in regular trash.

docs.title: Wear Protective Gear:
docs.text:
• Safety Glasses: Protect your eyes from copper dust and particles.
  • Dust Mask: Prevent inhalation of copper dust.
  • Gloves: Protect your hands from the sanding skin with sandpaper.

docs.title: Secure the Wire: (Optional)
docs.text: • Use a vise or clamp to securely hold the copper wire in place while sanding to prevent slipping and accidental injury. Vise Clamp

docs.title: Use Appropriate Sanding Tools:
docs.text: • Use fine-grit sandpaper to remove the insulator layer. Avoid using power tools, as they can remove too much material and generate excessive dust.

docs.title: Work in a Well-Ventilated Area:
docs.text: • Sand in a well-ventilated space to ensure you are not breathing in copper dust. An outdoor workspace is ideal.

docs.title: Clean Up Properly:
docs.text: • After sanding, clean the work area thoroughly to remove copper dust. Wash your hands and any exposed skin to avoid prolonged contact with copper particles.

docs.title: Avoid Excessive Force:
docs.text: • Apply gentle, even pressure while sanding to avoid damaging the wire and to maintain control of the sanding process.

docs.title: Store Tools Safely:
docs.text: • After use, store sandpaper and other tools in a safe place to prevent accidental contact.

docs.title: Read Instructions Carefully:
docs.text: • Follow all steps as outlined in the manual. Do not skip steps or take shortcuts.

docs.title: Keep a First Aid Kit Handy:
docs.text: • In case of minor injuries, have a first aid kit available for immediate treatment.

docs.title: Seek Help If Needed:
docs.text: • Don't hesitate to ask for assistance if you're unsure about any part of the process.
